hints_html: To find some characteristic trajectories near each critical point, you’ll need to compute the eigenvectors of the linearized systems - this will tell you what direction the trajectories move.
hints_latex:
To find some characteristic trajectories near each critical point,
you'll need to compute the eigenvectors of the linearized systems - this
will tell you what direction the trajectories move.
hints_raw: To find some characteristic trajectories near each critical point, you'll need to compute the eigenvectors of the linearized systems - this will tell you what direction the trajectories move.
question: 6 (b)
sols_html:
__NOTOC__ We will need to analyze the linearized system at each critical point.

At (x,y) = (0,0)

\[\begin{aligned} J = \begin{pmatrix}3 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

which has eigenvectors \((1,0)^T\) and \((0,1)^T\) with corresponding eigenvalues 3 and 1 respectively. The local solution structure centred at (0,0) is

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} = C_1 \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} e^{3t} + C_2 \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} e^t\end{aligned}\]

Along both eigenvectors, the trajectories move away, with the \((1,0)^T\) direction being dominant, since it is multiplied by the larger term, e3t.

At (x,y) = (0,1)

\[\begin{aligned} J = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

To find the eigenvector corresponding to \(\lambda = 2\), we seek the solution to \((J - 2 I) \vec{v} = \vec{0}\) so that

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{pmatrix}0 & 0 \\ 1 & -3 \end{pmatrix} \vec{v} = \vec{0}\end{aligned}\]

Or \(v_1 - 3v_2 = 0\), so we take \(\vec{v} = (3,1)^T\).

To find the eigenvector corresponding to \(\lambda = -1\), we seek the solution to \((J - (-1) I) \vec{v} = \vec{0}\) so that

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{pmatrix}1 & 0 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \vec{v} = \vec{0}\end{aligned}\]

Or v1 = 0, v2 = anything, so we take \(\vec{v} = (0,1)^T\).

The local solution structure centred at (0,1) is

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} = C_1 \begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} e^{2t} + \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} e^{-t}\end{aligned}\]

The solution grows exponentially along the \((3,1)^T\) direction and decays exponentially along the \((0,1)^T\) direction. Starting anywhere other than along the \((0,1)^T\) vector, the solution will approach the \((3,1)^T\) vector.

At (x,y) = (3,0)

\[\begin{aligned} J = \begin{pmatrix} -3 & -3 \\ 0 & 4 \end{pmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

To find the eigenvector corresponding to \(\lambda = -3\), we seek the solution to \((J - (-3) I) \vec{v} = \vec{0}\) so that

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{pmatrix}0 & -3 \\ 0 & 7 \end{pmatrix} \vec{v} = \vec{0}\end{aligned}\]

Or v2 = 0, v1 = anything, so we take \(\vec{v} = (1,0)^T\).

To find the eigenvector corresponding to \(\lambda = 4\), we seek the solution to \((J - 4 I) \vec{v} = \vec{0}\) so that

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{pmatrix}-7 & -3 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \vec{v} = \vec{0}\end{aligned}\]

Or \(-7 v_1 - 3v_2 = 0\), so we take \(\vec{v} = (-3,7)^T\).

The local solution structure centred at (3,0) is

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} = C_1 \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} e^{-3t} + \begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} e^{4t}\end{aligned}\]

The solution grows exponentially along the \((-3,7)^T\) direction and decays exponentially along the \((1,0)^T\) direction. Starting anywhere other than along the \((1,0)^T\) vector, the solution will approach the \((-3,7)^T\) vector.

At (x,y) = (1,2)

\[\begin{aligned} J = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & -1 \\ 2 & -2 \end{pmatrix},\end{aligned}\]

which as we saw in part (a) has complex eigenvalues with negative real part. By plugging in a point, say \((1,0)^T\) into the local linear system we can determine the direction of the spiral.

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{pmatrix} -1 & -1 \\ 2 & -2 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

which points up and to the left at (1,0). Therefore the spiral is counterclockwise.

This is all put together in the very rough global phase portrait.
sols_raw:
__NOTOC__
We will need to analyze the linearized system at each critical point.


=== At ''(x,y) = (0,0)'' ===

:<math>J = \begin{pmatrix}3 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}</math>

which has eigenvectors <math>(1,0)^T</math> and <math>(0,1)^T</math> with corresponding eigenvalues 3 and 1 respectively. The local solution structure centred at (0,0) is

:<math>\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} = C_1 \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} e^{3t} + C_2 \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} e^t</math>

Along both eigenvectors, the trajectories move away, with the <math>(1,0)^T</math> direction being dominant, since it is multiplied by the larger term, ''e<sup>3t</sup>''.


=== At ''(x,y) = (0,1)'' ===

:<math>J = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}.</math> 

To find the eigenvector corresponding to <math>\lambda = 2</math>, we seek the solution to <math>(J - 2 I) \vec{v} = \vec{0}</math> so that
:<math>\begin{pmatrix}0 & 0 \\ 1 & -3 \end{pmatrix} \vec{v} = \vec{0} </math>
Or <math>v_1 - 3v_2 = 0 </math>, so we take <math>\vec{v} = (3,1)^T</math>.

To find the eigenvector corresponding to <math>\lambda = -1</math>, we seek the solution to <math>(J - (-1) I) \vec{v} = \vec{0}</math> so that
:<math>\begin{pmatrix}1 & 0 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \vec{v} = \vec{0}</math>
Or ''v<sub>1</sub> = 0'', ''v<sub>2</sub> = anything'', so we take <math>\vec{v} = (0,1)^T</math>.

The local solution structure centred at (0,1) is

:<math>\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} = C_1 \begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} e^{2t} + \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} e^{-t} </math>

The solution grows exponentially along the <math>(3,1)^T</math> direction and decays exponentially along the <math>(0,1)^T</math> direction. Starting anywhere other than along the <math>(0,1)^T</math> vector, the solution will approach the <math>(3,1)^T</math> vector.


=== At ''(x,y) = (3,0)'' ===

:<math>J = \begin{pmatrix} -3 & -3 \\ 0 & 4 \end{pmatrix}.</math> 

To find the eigenvector corresponding to <math>\lambda = -3</math>, we seek the solution to <math>(J - (-3) I) \vec{v} = \vec{0}</math> so that
:<math>\begin{pmatrix}0 & -3 \\ 0 & 7 \end{pmatrix} \vec{v} = \vec{0}</math>
Or ''v<sub>2</sub> = 0'', ''v<sub>1</sub> = anything'', so we take <math>\vec{v} = (1,0)^T</math>.

To find the eigenvector corresponding to <math>\lambda = 4</math>, we seek the solution to <math>(J - 4 I) \vec{v} = \vec{0}</math> so that
:<math>\begin{pmatrix}-7 & -3 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \vec{v} = \vec{0}</math>
Or <math>-7 v_1 - 3v_2 = 0</math>, so we take <math>\vec{v} = (-3,7)^T</math>.

The local solution structure centred at (3,0) is

:<math>\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} = C_1 \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} e^{-3t} + \begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} e^{4t} </math>

The solution grows exponentially along the <math>(-3,7)^T</math> direction and decays exponentially along the <math>(1,0)^T</math> direction. Starting anywhere other than along the <math>(1,0)^T</math> vector, the solution will approach the <math>(-3,7)^T</math> vector.


=== At ''(x,y) = (1,2)'' ===

:<math>J = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & -1 \\ 2 & -2 \end{pmatrix}</math>, which as we saw in part (a) has complex eigenvalues with negative real part. By plugging in a point, say <math>(1,0)^T</math> into the local linear system we can determine the direction of the spiral.

:<math> \begin{pmatrix} -1 & -1 \\ 2 & -2 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} </math>

which points up and to the left at (1,0). Therefore the spiral is counterclockwise.

This is all put together in the very rough global phase portrait.

statement_html:
Suppose the interaction between two species (\(x=x(t)\) is the â€œpreyâ€ while \(y=y(t)\) is the predator) can be modelled by the autonomous system:

\[\begin{aligned} \left\{ \begin{array}{c} \frac{dx}{dt} = x\left(3-x-y\right) \\ \frac{dy}{dt} = y\left(1+x-y\right) \end{array} \right.\end{aligned}\]

(b) Sketch a phase portrait for the nonlinear system by first sketching a few trajectories near each critical point.
